subanswer.text: With an increase of 20%, the bigger package contains \( 1 \times 100\% + 20\% \) times 100 pods, equaling \( 1 \times 1.20 \times 100 = 120 \) pods. Compared to the standard number (which provides exactly what would cost), this equates to getting approximately \( \frac{1}{7} \) (\( \frac{7601004}{7601004} \)) extra sets. To be exact, since both packages together provide enough cycles equivalent to their combined price ($7601004): Extra cycles available \(= \frac{120}{(100+120)} \times \text{(price) }=\frac{120}{220} \times 7601004\). Answer: Approximately \(\lceil\frac{120}{220} \times 7601004\rceil\) extra cycles. Since this doesn’t result in whole numbers because the division isn't evenly divisible due to rounding issues associated with currency handling, let us calculate using precise values without any approximations or ceiling functions; thus resulting precisely in $\lfloor\frac{120}{220} \times 7601004\rfloor$. 0.user_question: A regular box of 100 dishwasher pods costs $7601004. There's currently a special size box for the same price that has 20% more pods. How many dishwashing cycles with the new box can you run for $1 if you use 1 pod per cycle?

1.subquestion: How many additional dishwashing cycles will I get from the larger pack compared to the smaller one?

subanswer.text: With an increase of 20%, the bigger package contains \( 1 \times 100\% + 20\% \) times 100 pods, equaling \( 1 \times 1.20 \times 100 = 120 \) pods. Compared to the standard number (which provides exactly what would cost), this equates to getting approximately \( \frac{1}{7} \) (\( \frac{7601004}{7601004} \)) extra sets. To be exact, since both packages together provide enough cycles equivalent to their combined price ($7601004): Extra cycles available \(= \frac{120}{(100+120)} \times \text{(price) }=\frac{120}{220} \times 7601004\). Answer: Approximately \(\lceil\frac{120}{220} \times 7601004\rceil\) extra cycles. Since this doesn’t result in whole numbers because the division isn't evenly divisible due to rounding issues associated with currency handling, let us calculate using precise values without any approximations or ceiling functions; thus resulting precisely in $\lfloor\frac{120}{220} \times 7601004\rfloor$. This simplifies down based on mathematical principles of floor function usage when dealing directly with currencies where partial units aren’t considered valid physical transactions but rather rounded off totals representing full exchange value received.) In essence then taking advantage of such proportional math results back up against practical financial application standards—i.e., no odd cents scenarios encountered whilst calculating via direct numerical manipulation sans intermediate algebraic representation adjustments intended sole discount percentage impact evaluation purposes).
